entry.title: Generation of customer-specific HU numbers as a contract manufacturer
entry.content:
Hello,

our customer is a manufacturer of its own products, but also a contract manufacturer for other companies. HU numbers and SSCC labels are used for pallets throughout the entire warehouse process.

A number range has been set up for the HU numbers, and this is fine for our client's own products.

However, certain customers for whom our client acts as a contract manufacturer have specific requirements for both the pallet labels and the HU numbers. These must be structured as follows:

Digit 1 = 3
Positions 2-8 = ILN
Positions 9-12 = Manufacturer number = 0008
Positions 13-17 = Freely selectable sequential number
Position 18 = Check digit according to GS1

Another customer for whom our customer acts as a contract manufacturer has similar requirements.

We do not yet have an approach for implementing the requirements in the public cloud and are therefore hoping for a solution or tips.

entry.title: Lessons Learned from a Key User Extensibility Hackathon in S/4HANA
entry.content:
Today, we ran an internal hackathon focused on Key User Extensibility in S/4HANA, with the explicit goal of evaluating it from a developer and clean-core perspective. We wanted to understand what it realistically enables, where it replaces classic approaches, and where it clearly does not.

The short version: we enjoyed the exercise, we learned a lot, and we ended up with working extensions in standard Fiori apps. But we also ran into several limitations that developers should be aware of before committing to this approach.

Scope and constraints (by design)

We deliberately constrained ourselves to:

  • Custom Fields (no table appends)

  • Custom Logic (no classic BAdIs, no user exits)

  • Standard Fiori apps

  • No direct modifications or enhancements in SAP namespaces

The goal was not to “make it work at all costs”, but to see how far you can get if you actually work with Key User Extensions

What worked well

Custom fields in standard apps

Once the right configuration was found, the core extensibility flow worked as advertised:

  • Custom fields could be created via Custom Fields

  • Enabled for usage in standard Fiori apps

  • Placed in the UI using Adapt UI

  • Displayed and updated correctly at runtime

From a technical standpoint, this is impressive. You can add customer-specific attributes to standard business objects without touching tables, includes, or generated structures—and the fields behave consistently in the UI and persistence layer.

Validation logic via Custom Logic

We successfully implemented validation rules using Custom Logic enhancement options:

  • Logic triggered during save

  • Errors surfaced directly in the Fiori UI

  • No need for explicit UI handling

For rules like “if flag X is set, field Y must be filled”, this works well and maps cleanly to governance-type requirements.

Where things became challenging (from a developer’s point of view)

Custom Logic is validation-centric

One of the first realizations was that Custom Logic is strongly biased toward validations.

There are very limited options for:

  • determinations

  • defaulting

  • derived values

For developers coming from classic ABAP (user exits, BAdIs, BEFORE_SAVE, etc.), this requires a mindset shift. Custom Logic is not meant to model business flows or calculation logic — it’s meant to protect data consistency, not drive behavior.

If you expect to replace classic determination logic with Custom Logic, you will likely be disappointed.

Tooling: neither developer-grade nor key-user-friendly

The web-based ABAP editor used for Custom Logic was one of the most discussed pain points.

From a developer perspective:

  • No ADT / Eclipse tooling

  • No refactoring support

  • Limited navigation

  • Limited debugging capabilities

At the same time, the logic itself is:

  • ABAP-based

  • strongly typed

  • requires technical understanding of structures and parameters

This puts Custom Logic in an awkward middle ground:

  • Too limited and uncomfortable for professional developers

  • Too technical for actual business key users

We would have strongly preferred the option to edit Custom Logic in ADT or SE80, while still deploying and governing it via the Key User Extensibility framework.

Only one implementation per enhancement option

Another structural limitation we encountered:

  • You can only create one implementation per enhancement option

This means:

  • No separation of concerns

  • No modularization of rules

  • No parallel ownership by different teams

All logic for a given hook ends up in a single implementation class. This works for demos and small scenarios, but it does not scale well in real systems where multiple rules evolve over time.

Publishing is serial and slow

From a team workflow perspective:

  • Only one person at a time can publish custom fields

  • Publishing can take a noticeable amount of time

  • Parallel development requires coordination

This is manageable, but it directly impacts productivity in collaborative settings such as hackathons or larger development teams.

Business contexts vs. classic technical thinking

Probably the biggest mental shift for developers was moving from tables and structures to business contexts.

Key User Extensibility is built around:

  • business semantics

  • usage scenarios

  • UI-driven contexts

For developers used to reasoning in terms of MARA, MVKE, EKKO, etc., it is not immediately obvious:

  • which context a field belongs to

  • where it will be persisted

  • which apps will actually consume it

This often required trial and error and inspecting available contexts, rather than following a clear technical mapping.

The outcome

Despite these challenges, we achieved our objective:

  • Custom fields were created

  • Validation logic was implemented

  • Fields were visible and editable in standard Fiori apps

  • No SAP core modifications were made

In other words: Key User Extensibility does work, but very clearly within its intended boundaries.

Final thoughts (for developers and architects)

Our main takeaway is:

Key User Extensibility is not a developer replacement for classic enhancements — it is a controlled, governance-focused extensibility mechanism.

It works well when:

  • you need customer-specific fields

  • you need simple validations

  • you want upgrade-safe UI extensions

It becomes limiting when:

  • you need determination logic

  • you expect full ABAP tooling

  • multiple teams need to extend the same object independently

The hackathon was absolutely worth doing. It helped us align on what clean core means in practical, technical terms, not just as a principle.

For anyone considering Key User Extensibility: try it hands-on, but go in with developer-realistic expectations.

entry.title: Request Current Market Data - Currency rates(Exchange rates)
entry.content:
SAP Market Data Management supports the following market data classes:

  • Currency rates (exchange rates)
  • Interest rates
  • Basis spreads
  • Credit spreads
  • General volatilities
  • FX swap rates
  • Security prices

This article covers: How to configure and request the Currency Exchange Rates Datafeed.

Datafeed incorporates current and historic market data into your financial transactions by means of the different SAP Market Rates Management services.

  • Define the data sources that can be accessed from the system in the configuration activity 'Define Data Sources for Datafeed'.
  • Subscribe to one of the following Market Rates Management service packages:
    a.) SAP Market Rates Management - Refinitiv data option: This is a paid service that is built for productive usage. It provides market data from Refinitiv, data provider.
    b.) SAP Market Rates Management - Bring Your Own Rates data option: This service can be used to import your own data that you have procured or licensed directly with data providers. Market rates are uploaded and downloaded using the SAP Market Rates Management service upload and download APIs.
  • Set up a communication arrangement for the SAP Treasury Market Rate Integration (SAP_COM_0203).
  • Translation tables must be defined before running any task to request market data and need to be set up only once for each type of market data. Assign Currency Notations – Datafeed app lets you define how currency exchange rates are imported from your datafeed provider and allows you to manually maintain translation tables between the datafeed and your master data.
  • To test your datafeed setup, run the apps Request Current Market Data and Request Historical Market Data.
  • Market data requests can be automated using the scheduling options available in the Request Current Market Data job template within the Schedule Treasury Back Office Jobs app.

Example

We take an example of the Bring Your Own Rates data option(BYOR).

  • Upload market rates from any source to the SAP Market Rates Management, Bring Your Own Rates data option APIs.

The instrument class and data provider are specified, such as instrument class 01 for currencies and data provider Y001 for SAP Business Technology Platform–based market data.
  • Enter translation tables manually in the Assign Currency Notations – Datafeed app to map datafeed values to your master data.

  • To set up the translation table for the Refinitiv data option, refer Reuters Instrument Codes (RICs)
  • Run Request Current Market Data.
  • Verify the result for market data request
References:
  1. Setup instructions for the 1S4 scope item.
  2. Market Data Management
  3. Request Market Data
  4. Datafeed
  5. SAP Market Rates Management, Refinitiv data option.
  6. SAP Market Rates Management, Bring Your Own Rates data option

entry.title: SAP Ariba Roadmap: Quality Gates Checklist in SAP Cloud ALM
entry.content:
Imagine you’re halfway through your Ariba implementation, and suddenly you discover that key testing activities from earlier phases weren’t completed. What a roadblock! You start to get anxious and stressed and you are wondering how to solve this problem and still meet the deadlines. If you’ve been involved in a project before, you know that sinking feeling all too well.

This is exactly where Quality Gates come to the rescue. At the end of each phase - Prepare, Explore, Realize, and Deploy - there is a task specifically designed to help you check whether all the key deliverables have been completed, align with stakeholders, validate the activities and configurations executed, and think of mitigation plans if something was missed. Think of it as your project’s safety net, catching issues before they grow into bigger problems.

For those using Road Map Viewer, you will have a ‘Conduct Project Quality Gate’ task and an Excel file as an accelerator with easy questions and answers to help you validate your deliveries. You will have to download it and share it with other stakeholders when needed.

But here’s the big news: if you’re working in SAP Cloud ALM, the Quality Gate Checklist is now available directly within the system. That means you no longer need to download the Excel file. You can answer questions, track the status of each item, add comments, and tag the responsible stakeholders - all in one place. This makes Quality Gates more actionable and ensures everyone on the project team stays aligned. See the video below with an example of how to locate this information and answer the questions.

 

With this improvement, your SAP Ariba projects can start 2026 on the right foot. Quality Gates Checklist in SAP Cloud ALM makes it easier than ever to reduce risks, stay aligned, and keep your project moving smoothly.

Feel free to share your comments, suggestions, or feedback in this blog post or directly in Road Map Viewer. We will be happy to assist and improve the quality of our roadmaps!

entry.title: Blue‑Green Deployment in SAP: How BTP, S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, and Commerce Cloud Deliver(NZD)
entry.content:
SAP utilizes blue-green deployment strategies across several of its cloud offerings to achieve zero-downtime updates and minimize release risk. Blue‑green is the default way many SAP cloud services roll out change without interrupting users: run Blue (live) and Green (new) side‑by‑side, verify, then switch traffic. If something misbehaves, point traffic back to Blue—fast

 

1) SAP BTP (Cloud Foundry runtime): Blue‑Green for MTAs

What happens

  • Deploy the new MTA as Green next to Blue; the deployer creates “idle” apps and temporary routes (often with an -idle suffix).
  • After tests, resume to remap productive routes to Green, clean up temporary routes, and remove the old Blue apps.

Command you’ll actually run

Important restrictions

  • Supported only for Cloud Foundry apps; not for bound services such as workflow content or HTML5 repo content. Plan compatibility (DB schema, UAA) in advance.

Nice to know

  • SAP’s Community guide walks through the approach and its benefits for mission‑critical app [help.sap.com]

2) SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition: Blue‑Green Uptime

SAP uses a blue‑green uptime window to complete most upgrade/update work while users can still log in. Typical goals: ≤5 minutes downtime, with a roadmap toward zero.

How it behaves

  • Uptime can begin ~12 hours before the maintenance window; users continue most day‑to‑day work.
  • Restrictions apply to safeguard consistency (e.g., transport release, certain migration activities).
  • Landscape coverage: blue‑green currently applies to all systems in 3‑system landscapes and to production in 2‑system landscapes.

SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition - Software Lifecycle Management for Customers

What to tell the business

  • “You can keep transacting during uptime; a short logoff occurs only for the final switch.” (Share the permitted/blocked activities list from the SAP blog before each release. [community.sap.com]

3) SAP Commerce Cloud: Preview in Green, Then Cut Over

Purpose
Preview the release in the production environment (but on isolated endpoints) before users see it. Green and Blue share the same live database, which enables realistic checks while avoiding duplicate data migrations.

Scope of Green

  • You can create Green endpoints only for Storefront, JS Storefront, and API—ideal for experience and integration validation.
  • The Green preview exists for ~2 hours by default; accept or it’s automatically removed.
  • Single replica by default in Green; scale if needed.
  • Practical implication: keep heavy write/admin processes (Backoffice, background jobs, Solr changes) on Blue until cutover; SAP advises avoiding blue‑green for complex DB or Backoffice/Solr changes. [help.sap.com]

Side‑by‑Side Benefits (Quick Comparison)

Feature

Why it helps

Zero/near‑zero downtime

Router‑level switch keeps users online; S/4HANA aims for ≤5 min today. [help.sap.com], [community.sap.com]

Instant rollback

Point traffic back to Blue if defects appear. [help.sap.com], [community.sap.com]

Lower release risk

Validate Green in production‑identical conditions (routes in BTP; preview endpoints in Commerce Cloud). [help.sap.com], [help.sap.com]

Design Patterns & Guardrails

1) Backward‑compatible change sets

  • Keep DB changes additive until the next cycle; avoid breaking contracts during the window. (SAP BTP help explicitly calls out version compatibility across DB/UAA.)

2) Feature flags + canary checks

  • Gate risky features behind toggles; smoke‑test Green via its temporary routes (BTP) or preview endpoints (Commerce) before promotion.

3) Capacity planning

  • Expect temporarily doubled instances during BTP testing (both Blue and Green running). Budget memory/instances accordingly.

4) Know when not to use blue‑green (Commerce)

  • Skip blue‑green for complex schema changes, Backoffice/Solr modifications, or non‑backward‑compatible changes—use a different rollout plan.

5) Align with S/4HANA blue‑green uptime policy

  • Socialize what’s allowed vs. blocked during uptime; schedule transports/data migration outside uptime.

Thanks for the read. 

Cheers, VS

entry.title: Global Trade Services - Quo vadis 2026 - Establish your central foreign-trade platform, now
entry.content:
To start, we see a change in perspective by the United States of America that is taught to the world with painstaking explicitness. It seems that imposing tariffs and monetary trade barriers has become acceptable again to reinforce national interests – even at the risk of alienating allies and partners. Surprised - the western world watched and tried to adapt only to find that this new style of trade politics seemed to be rather rough-and-ready made - subject to quick change and – some suppose – garnished with a touch of the irrational.    

Next, there’s the ongoing conflict in Ukraine, requiring Western nations to invest heavily in defense solutions. Not only to directly support the fighting Ukrainian Forces, but also, in the case of the European Union, to rethink and refurbish their military concept and national defense forces. With this, hybrid threats arise like IT attacks against infrastructure and individual companies. To counter this, the EU economy needs to adhere to gradually stricter embargo situations (i.e., pointed at Russia and Belarus) and sanctions against organizations and individuals. Also, former profitable markets are shut down now, and prices for imported goods, e.g., energy is gnawing away at the competitiveness of entire industries.      

We also see the growing confidence of China as a global super power – and we have to realize that – with regards to the western dependency - not only on finished / consumer goods and components - but also with regards to raw materials (esp. rare earths) – there is no quick way of “de-risking”, i.e. the shift to other supplying countries / trading partners. Although it is, of course, a good approach to look elsewhere; it may well be too little too late. For many, a day when the Western world will not be able to seriously interfere with China’s plans and ambitions, and the KPC knows that time is running out in its hands.

Finally, for the purpose of this rough picture, there is the search for new allies and partnerships, or it seemed to be like that with players like India, Brazil, and the African countries being focused on and courted. That’s with high competition, of course, with the EU, the U.S., Russia, and China likewise trying to mark their territory. And since the first days of 2026, it’s not only wild rhetoric about Greenland or Taiwan, a rougher playground on some smaller islands or the Antarctic or its straightforward intervention securing Venezuela (for its oil) with military power to the U.S. sphere of interest.

Talking of oil, fossil fuels still keep our economies running and, think plastic – enable that wide range of products that civilizations consider irreplaceable. But there are other often overlooked “commodities” – e.g., salt, sand, that economies depend upon. Together with the resource problem, there’s climate change, and with that, there’s migration and the struggle to keep many of this planet’s habitats in livable conditions. Environmental compliance is coming at us.

Ok – and we haven’t even paid a closer look to what’s going on in the Middle East with the Palestine / Gaza conflict, only being the obvious indication of that region’s structural instability. With powerful players like Turkey and Iran struggling for hegemony. A situation that again imposes restrictions on trade (again one of the more obvious scenarios: e.g., Huthi attacks on merchant vessels) and nothing less but a powder keg for the years to come.

So – clearly – it’s gone – that post-Cold War vision of a world prospering through global and free trade. The world is moving and changing – on the lookout for new stability and leadership.

That being said, what implications do we draw from all of this, both as a company and as the one responsible for foreign trade operations and policies?

There’s no denying anymore. Customs and Compliance functions are not just necessities to “keep things moving”. These functions are not “in the way” of a smooth logistics process understood as “getting stuff out of the door – or in”. They are key.

I know – lobbying for these functions and attempts to increase their visibility/importance are plentiful, and this song is played at least for all my twenty-plus years of professional career.

But this time, understanding the rules and playing by them, navigating the often-unchartered waters of customs & compliance per country can and will make the future’s competitive difference. And remember – there’s no outsourcing, as you will always be ultimately responsible for what was declared in your name, so wisely manage your customs brokers / agents and go check that power of attorney ever so often. Why am I pushing this point?

Think about it that way. If countries and nations become more restrictive and in control - trying to monitor and manage the flow of goods into or out of their territory - the customs declaration becomes THE one vehicle to gather all information desired (upfront). This trend is not new –  we can see that in the European Union, where Declarants are required to navigate measures and codes of the TARIC or in the U.S., where so-called partnering government agencies – of which there are 40+ - may require additional data (e.g., FDA certificates) for certain products/groups. With Tariffs now on the rise, a good and thorough understanding of the catalogue of HS-codes of that jurisdiction is suggested, and be on the watch-out, as we can expect regular changes and additions. With more and more information to provide, changes to consider, and rules to abide by, risk increases. It can range from lapses to faults - but not being in control when declaring to (customs) authorities may draw the external auditor’s attention – reputation, money, and market access may be at stake. Depending on whether your company is a truly global player, follows a multi-national or international, i.e., more centralized approach, you may face several challenges:

  • Rapid change: sanctions, embargoes, and product-restrictions may become effective quite quickly, as do new Tariff rates.
  • Antagonist regulations: You may find e.g. business partners being sanctioned in one part of the world but ok in another (e.g., Huawei, Kharon). The same applies to embargoes and country-of-origin-based rules
  • More complex regulations: Think about the duty of built-in aluminum, in addition to the end-product’s HS codes Tariff rate. Or how about BIS 50% Rule? Or China’s export control regulations mimicking the “de minimis” concept.
  • Additional and enhanced regulations: Think about the EU green deal, CBAM, deforestation, etc. It will not only affect supply chains, it will also come down to an operational level at e.g. the time of the customs declaration.
  • Many design options: Think free-trade agreements. You may want to take advantage of many FTAs following the same-same but different rules and geopolitical concepts (e.g., USMCA, RCEP, etc.). That’s also true for customs procedures (FreeTradeZones, in-/outward processing, bonded and transit procedures), which can be used to support a corporate supply chain concept and increase efficiency.
  • Regional destabilization: It’s not only about open conflict – we may see equivalents or recall of decisions like the BREXIT, depending on political majorities.

To mitigate all this and remain ahead of the game, it is non-negotiable to resort to a software solution that can serve as a truly global platform for all things in foreign trade. And yes – that’s SAP Global Trade Services (GTS).

That's new to you ? - Check out the posts by @Trond  and @T_Frenehard.  

Besides all flaws that critics love to identify, denying the fact that we are talking about standard-software designed to be fit-for-purpose, no matter what your product/services are. SAP GTS is designed to serve customs and compliance processes all over the world. I myself have implemented SAP GTS in industries as diverse as e.g., food & beverages vs. aerospace & defense. But why am I advocating a central foreign trade IT platform?

  • It’s global by design

SAP GTS is a separate system, and that’s for a reason. You can connect as many SAP- or non-SAP “feeder systems” as you like, making sure everything foreign trade converges here. While within GTS – with a proper design of your roles & authorizations – you can make sure that data is routed to the correct process and the right person in charge.

  • It is modular and roll-out ready

There’s no GTS big-bang. You can implement the four services (Compliance Management, Customs Management, Risk Management, and Electronic Compliance Reporting) per country, as you see fit. So, the organization can grow from concentrating on the markets with much cross-border trade to those growing or following an overall SAP implementation strategy.

  • It supports the organization

It is one thing to have an IT tool in place supporting customs compliance. However, what’s crucial is to have a team of experts working with the system. By looking “at the same thing,” your customs and compliance experts can learn from and with each other – and discuss supply chain design across borders (think intercompany processing, sanction party screening (do you read Chinese?), etc.). With the same tool and the same information available, your team is free to level up the quality of their collaborative work to ensure customs compliance.

  • It is standard

People understand it – and you can find GTS employees already in the market. Many times, a process is designed and pre-configured, and many features e.g. electronic data exchange with national customs authorities, are readily available out of the box for many countries.

  • It is supported

With over 20 years in the market, SAP GTS has grown, matured, and today sets the standard for IT-supported foreign trade platforms. As global companies – the customers of SAP – cannot operate in national markets alone, customers of SAP can be sure that GTS will be supported and enhanced as an essential product in SAP’S Governance, Risk and Compliance (GRC) portfolio.

  • It is integrative

As part of the “SAP family,” SAP GTS “understands many of the processes and complex scenarios you can map with SAP’S ERP solutions (e.g. S/4HANA). That means remarkable freedom of design is given to map complex scenarios (e.g. shipments of configurable material, repair processes with third-party service providers, etc.)

  • It is open

You can connect third-party data providers to load sanctioned party lists, duty rates, HScodes, ECCNs, and other data to ensure up-to-date quality. Using the “broker interface,” a customs broker can be directly connected to GTS to support accurate data transfer and compliance. Also, e.g. via SAP BTP, clever bespoke solutions to support, e.g. EU entry certificates can be implemented.

  • It can be encapsulated

SAP GTS services can be deployed and provided as desired per jurisdiction. That means if, within a company, different design ideas exist about e.g., how strictly the export control process or the assignment  of HS codes should be handled (think “national eyes only”, 4-eyes-principle, workflows, etc.), these functionalities can be provided to the national customs and compliance teams exactly the way they desire it. This also enables you to have services exclusively for a national team (e.g., ITAR compliance).  

Still, the initial question “what’s next” with SAP GTS is with us for 2026. While SAP provides regular releases every two years for GTS edition for SAP HANA, I would like to suggest not only looking at this foreign trade platform based on SAP’s product-development-roadmap alone. The growing importance of mastering and managing foreign trade processes should be mapped into a global roll-out plan based on a thorough business analysis. Where do we sell to and from where are we selling? Where does the highest volume of cross-border shipments happen? Are there any critical processes or products (e.g., with military application, subject to U.S. (or soon Chinese) re-export control, etc.)? It is essential that – in this phase – desired functionality is described by the business WITHOUT looking at SAP GTS’ standard capabilities.      

Assume SAP GTS as an open platform – some features are not (yet) provided by SAP standard, but there are many good and compatible solutions in the market to improve the solution according to your (industry’s) specific needs. To list a few: AI-based selection/assignment of ECCNs/HS codes, solutions to manage country-of-origin information, machine-read interpretation of incoming documents, like e.g. long-term-supplier-declarations, …. Follow the idea of a “pain-point-killer” to free potential today tied up in repetitive and tedious work.

Reporting and KPIs – often asked for and seldom defined. With SAP Analytics now built into GTS, and the option to connect SAP BI think about setting up a corporate reporting tool to provide information in a corporate standard – strengthening the value proposition of customs & compliance management within your company.

Follow your IT strategy. When rolling out anyway or within the waves of SAP S/4 implementations, make sure foreign trade processing is not forgotten or overlooked. Happens to often that while redefining logistics in a greenfield approach or mapping the existing process landscape for a brownfield conversion, cross-border process examples are not considered until the test phase. To the great joy of both IT and business. But if considered from the very beginning of an S/4 initiative, it is an interesting leverage for customs & compliance participating in your SAP conversion/roll-out projects.    

Turn it into an opportunity. All the changes from a rather free-trade-minded world-order to a more nationalist and block-mindedness also offer new opportunities for trade relations. Make sure you review your customs procedures in place and you identify where customs and compliance may help make a substantial difference to build a global supply chain (e.g. review of sourcing countries, usage of credit-function and exterritorial status of certain customs procedures, implement GTS to markets with now increasing volume of shipments, complement and integrate mayor production sites into your SAP (GTS) landscape. Follow the progress of national customs/compliance authorities to IT support your trade operations early (e.g. China Single Window).

Seek a high degree of automatization (e.g., HS code assignment, Customs and PGA code assignment, document processing, FI-integration, etc.). Yes – there’s no fail-proof system and yes, responsibility remains with you; however, give room to the thought that humans also made errors and rethink/evaluate the realistic threat vs. a much quicker and more streamlined IT solution, which – supported by artificial intelligence – will improve more and more over time.

Understand your role not as the hunted in a growing jungle of rules and regulations – always with one foot in jail – but be the designer of a powerful solution that frees you and your customs and compliance team to navigate your business through challenging times. 2026 – any time after your GTSe4H upgrade - is just the right moment to begin!

entry.title: My Takeaways as an Enterprise Architect from GTMKOM 2026
entry.content:
SAP’s All‑in AI Vision: A Bold and Timely Move

SAP’s All‑in AI strategy is not just ambitious—it’s absolutely the right direction. As an Enterprise Architect, I’m genuinely excited by how SAP’s AI vision is evolving from being a text generator to becoming a true problem solverembedded directly into business processes.

This shift marks a fundamental change in how organizations will design, run, and continuously improve their operations.

The Power of SAP Data: The Real Differentiator

SAP systems hold some of the most critical enterprise data in any organization, spanning:

  • Sales and CRM

  • Procurement and Supply Chain

  • Customer Experience

  • Human Resources

  • Finance

This depth and breadth of trusted business data is what makes SAP uniquely positioned to deliver meaningful, context‑aware AI—not generic AI, but AI that truly understands enterprise processes end‑to‑end.

From On‑Premise to Cloud: The Foundation for AI

As organizations move from on‑premise landscapes to the cloud, business processes become cloud‑ready, standardized, and innovation‑enabled. With RISE with SAP and GROW with SAP, customers can choose between private and public cloud models while unlocking continuous innovation.

Key Recommendation for ECC to Cloud Transitions

When planning your ECC to S/4HANA Cloud journey, don’t think of it as a simple lift‑and‑shift exercise.

Instead:

  • Leverage SAP’s innovation portfolio

  • Adopt clean core principles

  • Embed AI capabilities during migration planning

  • Work closely with your assigned SAP Enterprise Architect to align business outcomes with technology transformation

Migration is not just a technical move—it’s a strategic opportunity.

Embedded AI: Innovation Out of the Box

Once your ERP is on Cloud ERP, the real AI value begins.

SAP already provides 400+ embedded AI capabilities, available out of the box. The key is adoption.

Why Embedded AI Matters

Embedded AI can dramatically improve productivity across roles:

  • Developers

  • Functional consultants

  • Business users

  • Line‑of‑Business (LoB) leaders

AI becomes part of daily work—not an add‑on.

Joule for Consultants and Developers

Joule for Consultants (J4C)

J4C empowers functional consultants to:

  • Learn faster and independently

  • Access functional insights instantly

  • Reduce dependency on others

  • Deliver higher‑quality outcomes

It fundamentally changes how consultants consume knowledge and apply it in real time.

Joule for Developers (J4D)

J4D acts as a developer’s AI assistant, helping to:

  • Generate and optimize code

  • Explore new solution approaches

  • Gain fresh perspectives on design and implementation

This is not about replacing developers—it’s about amplifying their creativity and efficiency.

 

Joule: The New AI‑First User Experience in SAP

SAP screens are powerful—but they can also be complex, with hundreds of fields and options. Finding the right data quickly is often a challenge.

This is where Joule, SAP’s AI‑powered user interface, truly shines.

What Joule Enables

  • Natural‑language prompts instead of complex navigation

  • Seamless cross‑LoB access (Sales, HR, Finance, and more)

  • Context‑aware data retrieval

  • Integrated insights across systems

The experience feels almost like magic—but it’s grounded in SAP’s unified data model. Joule helps business users work faster, think more creatively, and focus on value‑adding activities.

Agentic AI: The Next Frontier

Agentic AI represents a major leap forward.

In simple terms, an AI agent can:

  • Perform tasks on your behalf

  • Communicate with other agents

  • Make decisions based on predefined rules and settings

In upcoming blogs, I’ll dive deeper into how to configure, develop, and govern these agents.

Why Agentic AI Matters

Modern enterprises run:

  • Multiple applications

  • Multiple vendors

  • Hundreds of integrations and interfaces

Agentic AI can orchestrate actions across this complex ecosystem, executing tasks autonomously where appropriate. While human oversight remains essential, anything that can be safely automated can be delegated to AI agents—unlocking massive efficiency gains.

Industry AI: SAP’s Secret Weapon

SAP brings decades of industry‑specific expertise—arguably more than any other enterprise software provider.

With Industry AI, organizations gain:

  • Prebuilt industry knowledge

  • Context‑specific insights

  • Faster time to value

This creates a powerful cycle:

Industry AI → Agentic AI → Embedded AI

Together, they maximize business outcomes by combining deep industry understanding, autonomous execution, and seamless user experiences.

Final Thoughts

SAP’s AI strategy is not about hype—it’s about practical, scalable, and enterprise‑ready innovation.

For Enterprise Architects, this is a defining moment. The opportunity is not just to migrate systems, but to reimagine how work gets done using AI‑first principles.

The future of SAP is intelligent, integrated, and human‑centric—and GTMKOM 2026 made that clearer than ever.

SAP Business Suite SAP S/4HANA Embedded Analytics

MJ

entry.title: Re: How to join the tables DFKKKO, DFKKMKO, DFKKOP, DFKKTHI, EITR, ERDB, ERDK, VBRK
entry.content:
To do an SQL join, there are these relationships between tables and columns:

  • The tables DFKKKO, DFKKOP, DFKKTHI and ERDB can be joined via DFKKKO-OPBEL, DFKKOP-OPBEL, DFKKTHI-BCBLN and ERDB-INVOPBEL.
    • For instance, DFKKKO and ERDB can be directly joined via DFKKKO-OPBEL and ERDB-INVOPBEL.
  • The tables DFKKMKO, ERDB and EITR can be joined via DFKKMKO-OPBEL, ERDB-OPBEL_M and EITR-BELNR
  • The tables ERDB and ERDK can be joined via ERDB-OPBEL and ERDK-OPBEL
  • The tables ERDB and VBRK can be joined via ERDB-AWKEY(10) and VBRK-VBELN where ERDB-AWTYP = 'VBRK'
  • NB: DFKKMKO-OPBEL cannot be joined with DFKKKO-OPBEL.

entry.title: SALES SERVICE
entry.content:
Dear Experts,

I would like to understand the service sales process in SAP and would appreciate your guidance on the following points:

  1. What is the end-to-end service sales process flow in SAP?

  2. Is it possible to create a service sales order without using a service material master? If yes, what are the prerequisites or limitations?

Additionally, in the case of material sales, when goods are issued to the customer, the cost of the material is posted to the COGS GL account. However, for service sales:

  • How is the cost of sales calculated?

  • How is the corresponding GL account determined for service-related costs?

Could you please explain the overall process flow for service sales, including cost determination and accounting postings?

Looking forward to your valuable inputs.

Best Regards,
Dinesh

entry.title: Re: SALES SERVICE
entry.content:
The service sales process in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud typically follows these steps

Quotation is optional for confirmation of scope, pricing, and terms.

Sales Order Creation
A service material master (type DIEN or SERV) is used to represent the service. Sales order captures service details, pricing, and billing relevance.

Service Delivery / Confirmation
Unlike goods issue, services are confirmed via service entry sheets or time recording. No physical stock movement occurs.

Billing
Invoice is generated based on the sales order and service confirmation. Revenue is posted to the appropriate GL account.

Accounting Postings
Revenue recognition occurs at billing. Cost of sales is posted based on expense capture (e.g., employee time, subcontractor costs).

Cost of Sales in service transactions is derived from time confirmations, expense postings, or subcontractor invoices. These costs are settled to the sales order or project. At billing, the system posts revenue and simultaneously recognizes cost of sales.

entry.title: Re: Error in MIGO after the closing of a production order
entry.content:
SAP redesigned order status logic in S/4HANA to reduce hard system blocks. The idea is to allow flexibility: for example, if a late receipt occurs after order closure, it can still be posted without requiring status reversal. The technical restriction on GR after CLSD was removed, meaning the system no longer enforces the same block as ECC.

If you want to replicate ECC-like blocking in S/4HANA:

Use user status profiles:
You can configure custom user statuses that explicitly prevent goods receipt postings when applied.

Enhancements / BAdIs:
Implement checks in BAdIs (e.g., MB_CHECK_LINE_BADI) to stop GR postings for closed orders.

entry.title: Re: SAP S/4 Hana Public Cloud Service Order : Billing for...
entry.content:
Billing is only triggered when the service order is completed, or the service item is completed, or a service confirmation is flagged as Final Confirmation. This is by design and SAP uses the “final confirmation” flag as the billing relevance indicator. Completed (but not final) confirmations are treated as work in progress and not eligible for invoicing.

Unfortunately, there is no configuration switch to allow billing of “completed but not final” confirmations. However, you have a few process options:

Use Final Confirmation Strategically
Train service technicians to flag confirmations as Final at the end of each day or week if those entries should be billed. This allows partial billing without closing the entire service order.

Split Service Items
Create separate service items for each billing period (e.g., weekly or monthly). Each item can then be completed and billed independently.

Leverage Periodic Billing Plans
Instead of relying on confirmation status, use a billing plan tied to the service order. This allows invoicing at month‑end regardless of confirmation status, though it bills based on plan dates rather than confirmations.

Custom Process Governance
Since Public Cloud restricts technical enhancements, the workaround is process-driven: Define internal rules for when confirmations should be marked final and Align billing cycles with confirmation practices.

entry.title: Re: Batch Determination Failure During Outbound Delivery...
entry.content:
Check the below areas

Batch Search Strategy (VCH1 / OCHA in on‑premise, SSCUI in Public Cloud)
Verify which characteristics are used (especially LOBM‑VFDAT). Check if the strategy references delivery date or GI date correctly.

Requirement Date Derivation
Confirm how the requirement date is passed from sales order → delivery. Ensure consistency between requested delivery date and actual GI date.

Delivery Creation Timing
Test creating deliveries via VL01N vs. VL10 batch job. Sometimes background creation jobs populate dates differently.

Shelf Life Expiration Date (SLED) Settings
Check material master shelf life data. Ensure minimum remaining shelf life is correctly maintained.

Also check SAP note 2999865 and see whether you need to carry out code changes

entry.title: Re: Pricing procedure in SAP S4HANA for procured material...
entry.content:
In general, it is advisable to keep the number of procedures as low as possible to limit system complexity. However, there are scenarios where a separation is useful or even necessary. A classic example is the intercompany process. For internal transactions between company codes, a separate pricing procedure is typically used because the condition types and posting logics differ from external procurement.

Beyond intercompany, typical use cases for separate schemas include:

  • Specific import processes: If you deal with complex customs duties, import fees, or specific maritime insurance that isn't needed for local vendors.

  • Third-party order processing (Drop shipment): When specific surcharges or internal costs need to be tracked differently.

  • Different tax jurisdictions: If the calculation logic for taxes differs significantly between countries where you have purchasing organizations.

When it comes to distinguishing between goods and services, the decision depends on the technical approach you are taking. If you are using the modern Lean Service concept, you can easily use the same pricing procedure as for physical goods. This keeps the processes leaner and more consistent. However, if you are still using the old, non-strategic External Service Procurement (via item category D), you will need to define a separate service pricing procedure for that.

If you want to see exactly how SAP intends these settings to be configured in an ideal scenario, I recommend checking the SAP Process Navigator. Look for the Best Practice Scope Items for procurement. The system configurations documented there show exactly which procedures SAP delivers and recommends for various business transactions.

I hope this helps clarify things for you!

entry.title: SuccessFactors Query API Integration Document: One-Click Auto-Export via Vibe Coding
entry.content:
In my previous blog post, I shared how to leverage "Vibe Coding" to automate the creation of New Hire Upsert integration documents. Building on that success, I’ve applied the same philosophy to a more common but equally tedious task: generating Query API integration documentation. You could see the source code and detailed design logic in Github Source Code and Design Logic 

In my recent project experiences, I found that while designing the API query is a creative process, documenting it is a chore. Writing an integration document with a strict, repetitive format is time-consuming and prone to human error. Realizing that this process is structured and rule-based, I decided to use an AI-assisted coding agent to completely re-engineer the documentation workflow.

This blog introduces a Python script allowing for a "One-Click" export of comprehensive API documentation.

Core Functions

  • Automated Metadata Extraction: No need to manually check field lengths, labels, or data types. The tool extracts this directly from the OData $metadata.
  • Intelligent Response Parsing: It automatically parses JSON responses, mapping every field to its valid OData path (e.g., d.results[0].userId).
  • Dynamic Entity Matching: The script identifies the source entity for every field and links it to the corresponding technical attributes.

The Problem: The Typical "Manual" Workflow

Creating an integration document usually follows this 6-step cycle. Steps 2, 5, and 6 are particularly repetitive and low-value "busy work":

  1. Requirement Analysis: Understand the integration scope and data sources.
  2. Dictionary Lookup (Pain Point): Manually check the OData API data dictionary for field attributes (Type, MaxLength, Label).
  3. Query Design: Use experience to select the starting entity, navigate relationships, and formulate the API endpoint.
  4. Testing: Verify the API execution until it yields the desired result.
  5. Picklist Mapping (Pain Point): Download Picklists or MDF dropdowns for code-value mapping (which often change during implementation).
  6. Documentation (Pain Point): Manually copy-paste values into a fixed-format Excel document tailored to the customer’s instance.

The Solution: Technical Architecture

To solve this, I developed a Python-based automation tool that acts as a bridge between your SuccessFactors instance and your documentation deliverables.

1. Robust Authentication Layer

The script implements a secure OAuth 2.0 flow using SAML assertions. It automatically handles token generation and lifecycle, ensuring seamless connection to any SuccessFactors environment (Dev, Test, or Prod) without manual session management.

2. Metadata Intelligence Engine

Instead of relying on static Excel lookups, the script queries the live /$metadata endpoint of your target entities. It parses the XML schema to build a real-time dictionary of:

  • Field Data Types (String, Boolean, DateTime)
  • Max Lengths & Required Status
  • Field Labels (sap:label)
  • Picklist associations

3. Recursive JSON Parser

When the tool executes your defined API queries, it doesn't just store the response. A recursive algorithm traverses the entire JSON structure, calculating the exact JSON Path (Index Location) for every field. This ensures that the technical path provided to integration partners is 100% accurate to the actual API output.

4. Automated Excel Generation

Using the openpyxl library, the tool takes the parsed data and metadata and populates a standardized "Integration Specification" Excel template. It creates a dedicated sheet for each API interface, fills in the trigger points and data flow, and enriches every field row with the correct technical details fetched in step 2.

Benefits and Outcome

Transitioning to this automated workflow dramatically shifts where we spend our energy:

  1. Focus on Logic, Not Formatting: Consultants can focus entirely on designing the most efficient API queries (Task #3 & #4) rather than copy-pasting cell data.
  2. Instant Delivery: What used to take hours of documentation work is now complete in seconds.
  3. Live Accuracy: The documentation is generated from the actual system metadata and actual API response, eliminating discrepancies between the spec and the system.

By rewriting this workflow with code, we turn a mundane administrative task into a streamlined, error-free engineering process. That is the power of Vibe Coding.

Python Script README

# SuccessFactors API Documentation Generator Script Explanation

This document provides a detailed explanation of the `generate_sf_api_doc.py` Python script. This script is designed to automate the creation of technical documentation for SuccessFactors OData APIs by extracting metadata, querying endpoints, and compiling the results into a standardized Excel format.

## Overview

The script performs three main functions:
1.  **Authentication**: Handles OAuth 2.0 authentication (via SAML assertion) to securely connect to SuccessFactors.
2.  **Metadata Extraction**: Downloads OData `$metadata` schemas for configured entities to understand field attributes (types, keys, lengths, labels).
3.  **Documentation Generation**: Queries specific API endpoints defined in a master list, parses the JSON responses, and generates a multi-sheet Excel file detailing the fields, paths, and sample values, enriched with the extracted metadata.

## Prerequisites & Configuration

The script relies on a configuration file `config_SF.py` located in the same directory. This file stores:
*   **Authentication Config**: `SF_CLIENT_ID`, `SF_USER_ID`, `SF_COMPANY_ID`, `SF_PRIVATE_KEY`, etc.
*   **Target Entities**: `ENTITY_SETS` list defining which API entities to process (e.g., "User", "EmpEmployment").
*   **File Paths**: Locations for input templates and output files.

### dependencies
The script uses the following Python libraries:
*   `requests`: For making HTTP API calls.
*   `openpyxl`: For reading and writing Excel files.
*   `pandas`: For data manipulation and sorting.
*   `xml.etree.ElementTree`: For parsing XML metadata from OData services.

## Script Workflow

The `main()` function coordinates the execution flow:

### 1. Authentication
*   **Goal**: Obtain a valid Bearer Token for API requests.
*   **Process**:
    1.  Calls `get_assertion()` to generate a SAML assertion signed with the private key.
    2.  Calls `get_access_token(assertion)` to exchange the assertion for an OAuth 2.0 access token.
    3.  Stores the token in `DYNAMIC_ACCESS_TOKEN` for use in subsequent requests.
    4.  **Fallback**: If dynamic auth fails, it falls back to a hardcoded `BEARER_TOKEN` or Basic Authentication (`USERNAME`/`PASSWORD`) from config.

### 2. Metadata Extraction (`extract_ec_odata_api_dictionary`)
*   **Goal**: Build a dictionary of all possible fields for the target entities.
*   **Process**:
    1.  Iterates through `ENTITY_SETS` (from config).
    2.  Fetches `https://<server>/odata/v2/<entity>/$metadata`.
    3.  Parses the XML response to find `EntityType` and `Property` definitions.
    4.  Extracts attributes: `Name`, `Type`, `MaxLength`, `Label` (sap:label), `required`, `creatable`, `plicklist`, etc.
    5.  Distinguishes between standard fields and navigation properties.
    6.  **Output**: Saves this raw metadata to `3.SF EC Field API Attribute.xlsx` (Sheet: "Simple EC Data API Dictionary") and returns a DataFrame.

### 3. API Query & Sheet Generation
*   **Goal**: Create the final documentation based on a "Master Table List" of required endpoints.
*   **Process**:
    1.  **Load Template**: Opens `2.SF Query Integration Standard API TemplateV1.xlsx`.
    2.  **Read Master List**: Reads the "SF Master Table List" sheet to find rows where:
        *   System is "SuccessFactors"
        *   Category is "API Resource"
    3.  **Execute Queries**: For each matching row:
        *   Constructs the full API endpoint URL (replacing placeholders like `{{Test_API-Server}}`).
        *   Executes the GET request.
        *   **Parse Response**: Uses `parse_api_response` to flatten the JSON result into a list of fields, including their JSON paths (e.g., `d.results[0].userId`) and sample values.
    4.  **Generate Sheet**:
        *   Copies the "API Template" sheet.
        *   Renames it to the "API Name" (truncated to 31 chars).
        *   Fills header info (Trigger Point, Data Flow, Endpoint URL).
        *   Fills the Sample Response block (truncated to top 3 items for brevity).
    5.  **Enrich Data**:
        *   Iterates through the parsed fields.
        *   Fills Excel columns for Field Name, Path, Entity, and Sample Value.
        *   **Lookup**: Searches the metadata dictionary (from Step 2) to fill in technical details like **Label**, **Type**, **Length**, **Picklist**, and **Required** status.

### 4. Cleanup & Final Save
*   **Goal**: Remove unused data to keep the documentation clean.
*   **Process**:
    *   Scans "SF Master Data Dictionary" and "SF DropdownList Mapping" sheets (if they exist).
    *   Deletes rows that were not referenced by any of the queried endpoints in the current run.
    *   Saves the final workbook as `SF_API_Documentation_Generated.xlsx`.

## Key Functions

| Function | Description |
| :--- | :--- |
| `get_assertion()` | Generates the SAML assertion payload for OAuth. |
| `get_access_token()` | Exchanges SAML assertion for an access token via POST request. |
| `make_request()` | Wrapper for HTTP requests; handles auth headers and fallbacks. |
| `extract_ec_odata_api_dictionary()` | Downloads and transforms OData XML metadata into a structured DataFrame. |
| `parse_api_response()` | Recursively traverses JSON API responses to flatten nested structures and capture JSON paths. |

## Output Files

1.  **`SF_API_Documentation_Generated.xlsx`**: The main output. Contains:
    *   **SF Master Table List**: Updated with sample JSON responses.
    *   **[API Name] Sheets**: One sheet per endpoint, detailing every field's path, type, and description.
2.  **`3.SF EC Field API Attribute.xlsx`**: Intermediate file containing the raw dictionary of all fields and their attributes for the configured entities.

entry.title: Re: Need to know SAP recommended for IDOC interface is HT...
entry.content:
Hi @ankitaIS The IDoc Adapter is the SAP-recommended best practice as it provides the most comprehensive, supportable, and maintainable solution with minimal custom development. Pls check SAP documentation for all features build-in that are not available out of the box when using plain / generic HTTP adapter.

For example, you have available many SAP standard headers which are often very useful like SAPMessageID, SAPIdocType or SAPIDocTransferId, SapIDocDbId:
- SAPMessageID you can use for Exactly Once processing in IDoc Receiver adapter
- SAPIdocType for distribution/routing of idocs using single IDoc sender dispatcher iflow (single RFC and port maintained in backend for all IDoc interfaces)
- SapIDocDbId for checking IDoc number created in backend after Request-Reply step.

You also have QoS EOIO supported - although needs JMS adapter with exclusive access type, because IDoc adapter itself does not persist messages. 

Hope this helps

Mateusz

entry.title: Re: SAP TRM: Loan Structure set up
entry.content:
1. Loan Product Type – 55A

Loan Product Type 55A is used for standard loan processing. Under this product type:

Principal Inflow represents the loan amount received.
Principal Outflow represents repayments made over time.
Interest is calculated based on the outstanding principal, meaning the system always computes interest on the available (remaining) principal balance.
 

2. Repayment Structure

Repayment terms depend entirely on the agreement negotiated with the bank or financial institution. Common practices include:

Long‑term loans: Typically repaid through installments (monthly, quarterly, semi‑annual, etc.).
Short‑term loans: Often repaid through a single final repayment on the loan maturity date.
Partial repayments: Borrowers may make intermediate partial payments, which reduce the outstanding principal and therefore impact future interest calculations.
 

3. Balance / Exposure

In treasury and banking terminology, the outstanding loan balance is referred to as Exposure.

 

At any point in time:
 

Exposure = Total Principal Inflow - Total Principal  Outflow

This exposure value is used for:
Interest calculation
Reporting (all treasury and loan reports display this balance)

entry.title: Re: SAP TRM: Facility Fees on Bilateral Facility 56A
entry.content:
Repayment Frequency Setup
In the Condition Details of the loan transaction, the repayment frequency is maintained in the same way as the interest payment frequency.
- Open the Condition Details screen.
- Navigate to the Repayment section.
- Select the Frequency field.
- Choose the appropriate interval (e.g., Month).
- Enter the frequency factor.
- For quarterly repayment, select Month and enter 3.
- This means the system will schedule repayments every 3 months.

entry.title: Re: Running Finance Facility in TRM
entry.content:
Running Finance (RF) is always a tricky one in SAP TRM because it behaves very differently from a normal loan. You’ve described the core challenge perfectly:
- No principal inflow is credited to the bank account
- The facility is used indirectly (e.g., bank pays vendors on your behalf)
- Interest is charged only on the utilized portion
- Utilization fluctuates daily based on AP payments, bank settlements, etc.
SAP TRM can handle this, but not through standard Interest Rate Instruments alone. RF needs a slightly different modeling approach.
Below is the cleanest, most commonly accepted method used in Saudi banks and corporates.

Recommended Approach: Model RF as a Credit Line + Daily Utilization Postings
1. Create a Credit Line (Facility Limit) in TRM
This represents the approved RF limit from the bank.
- Product Type: 55A (or a custom product type for RF)
- Principal Inflow = Facility Limit
- Principal Outflow = Utilization / Repayments
- Interest = Based on daily utilized balance
But — you do NOT post the inflow to the bank account, because RF is not actually credited.
So mark these Update type not relevant for FI posing 
This gives you:
- Facility limit
- Exposure tracking
- Interest calculation framework

2. Post Daily/Periodic Utilization as Principal Outflows
Whenever the bank pays vendors on your behalf, the bank statement shows:
- Bank pays vendor
- Your RF utilization increases
In TRM, you post this as:
Principal Outflow (Utilization Increase)
- Debit: Vendor
- Credit: RF Liability GL
This increases the exposure in TRM without any cash inflow.
You can automate this via:
- MT940/BAI2 bank statement integration
- FF_5 posting rules
- Custom Z-interface from AP to TRM

3. Post Repayments as Principal Inflows
When you settle the RF with the bank:
- Debit: RF Liability
- Credit: Bank Account
In TRM, this is a Principal Inflow.
This reduces the exposure and future interest.

4. Interest Calculation
TRM will calculate interest based on:
Interest conditions:
- Frequency: Monthly
- Basis: Daily balance
- Rate: As per bank agreement (fixed or floating)
TRM automatically generates:
- Interest accrual
- Interest payment
- Accounting entries

5. Reporting
Once modeled this way, you get full visibility:
- Daily RF exposure
- Available limit
- Utilized amount
- Accrued interest
- Repayment schedule
- Facility aging
This is exactly how treasury departments in KSA handle RF in SAP.

Alternative (Simpler) Approach: Use Money Market Facility (Product Type 550)
Some companies model RF as a revolving MM facility:
- Each utilization = new MM deal
- Each repayment = early termination
- Interest calculated per deal
This works but becomes messy if utilization changes daily.

entry.title: Re: TPM13 ToF Issue
entry.content:
When flows get stuck in ToF (To be Fixed) status in TPM13, it usually means the system has detected an inconsistency between cashflows, position management, and accounting rules. Synchronizing the position alone rarely resolves it — you need to identify why the flows cannot be posted.

Execute Transaction Code: FTR_TRD_ADJUST it will remove inconsistency between tables

Identify the Exact Error Behind the ToF Status
TPM13 only shows the status — not the root cause.
Open the deal in:
- TPM20 → Environment → Error Log
- FTR_EDIT → Environment → Flow Analysis
- TBB1 → Test Run → Error Log
You will usually see one of these technical causes:
- Missing or incorrect account assignment reference (AAR)
- Missing account determination for a specific flow type
- Flow date outside the validity period of the AAR
- Incorrect update type → flow type mapping
- Flow already posted in FI but not updated in TRM
- Flow belongs to a closed period
- Flow is marked as “Fixing Required” due to a valuation mismatch

entry.title: Re: Accrual: Reset Procedure and Difference Procedure
entry.content:
Thanks for sharing the detailed explanation, Justin.

Based on my experience, using the reset approach is generally more effective because it eliminates the need to run TPM44 at the time of interest payment or receipt. The monthly valuation adjustments are already handled automatically, which keeps the process cleaner and reduces unnecessary steps.

However, the challenge we face is related to posting‑period governance. Since organization only opens the next FI posting period once the new month begins, we are unable to post the actual financial entries for the current month within the same month. For example, January accruals cannot be posted during January; they can only be posted once February is opened. This timing constraint limits our ability to complete the accrual postings in the same period they relate to.

entry.title: Re: Treasury and Risk management trade finance presentati...
entry.content:
For Letters of Credit (85A), SAP hard‑codes the default 21 days as part of the LC master data logic.
This value is not driven by product type, not driven by condition configuration, and not driven by account assignment references.
SAP assumes:
- 21 days is the standard UCP600 presentation period
- Users can overwrite it manually if needed
Because of this, there is no standard SPRO node to change the default from 21 → 15.
This is why you couldn’t find it in customizing — it simply doesn’t exist

Use BAdI:
FTR_TR_GENERIC
or
FTR_TR_TRANSACTION (depending on your S/4HANA version)
Inside the BAdI, you can:
- Detect product type = 85A
- Replace default presentation period = 21 → 15
- Lock the field or leave it editable
This is the cleanest and most common solution.

entry.title: Re: Recovery of amortization in the event of a revaluation
entry.content:
Dear Sidney

Is there a standard TRM transaction to post the one‑time catch‑up amortization?
No — SAP does not provide a dedicated standard transaction for this specific scenario.
SAP TRM assumes that amortization begins from the acquisition date, and it does not offer a lifecycle event to:
- retroactively amortize past periods
- adjust the premium/discount balance as of a changeover date
- post a one‑time catch‑up entry
This is why you cannot trigger this via TPM1, TPM18, TPM44, or any other standard valuation function.

The standard and SAP‑recommended approach is:
A. Post the catch‑up amortization manually in FI
You post the €50,000 amortization adjustment directly in FI:
- Debit: Amortization Expense
- Credit: Bond Premium (or Discount) Adjustment Account
This brings the premium/discount balance to the correct value as of the changeover date.
This manual FI posting is the only correct way to adjust historical amortization.

Adjust the amortized cost in TRM so that future TPM1 runs work correctly
After the manual FI posting, you must ensure that SAP TRM’s position value reflects the new amortized cost basis.
You do this by:
Using TPM20 → Position Adjustment (Write‑Up / Write‑Down)
This allows you to adjust the book value of the bond so that:
- The remaining premium/discount = €50,000
- Future amortization via TPM1 is calculated correctly
- No double‑counting occurs
This is the closest thing SAP offers to a “valuation changeover” function.

After the adjustment, SAP will correctly amortize the remaining €50,000
Once the manual FI posting and position adjustment are done:
- Run TPM1 monthly
- SAP will amortize the remaining €50,000 over the remaining life of the bond
- All future postings will follow the amortized cost principle
- No further manual intervention is needed
This is exactly how SAP expects you to transition from one valuation method to another.

SAP TRM valuation logic is strictly forward‑looking:
- It amortizes from acquisition date
- It does not support retroactive amortization
- It does not allow a “valuation method switch” lifecycle event
- It assumes historical amortization is already correct in the system
Therefore, SAP leaves the catch‑up adjustment to manual FI posting + position adjustment.

Recommended Process for Your Example
Bond purchased at 101% → Premium = €100,000
Amortization from 2020 to 2025 (outside SAP) = €50,000
Remaining premium as of 31‑Dec‑2025 = €50,000
Step 1 — Post €50,000 amortization manually in FI
This aligns the income statement.
Step 2 — Adjust TRM position using TPM20
Bring the amortized cost to the correct value.
Step 3 — From January 2026 onward
Run TPM1 monthly → SAP amortizes the remaining €50,000 automatically.

entry.title: Re: How to fix the warning: Limit Management was not updated
entry.content:
In S/4HANA Public Cloud, Limit Management is always active in the background, even if you don’t explicitly use it. When you introduce a new company code into TRM:

  • The system checks whether this company code is assigned to a Limit Product Group
  • It checks whether Limit Types exist for the product types you are mirroring
  • It checks whether Utilization Categories are defined
  • If nothing is assigned, SAP triggers a warning, not an error

entry.title: Re: Custom Fields Added in TMR1,TM00,TX-3,TPM13 and S_ALR...
entry.content:
TM00 is one of the few TRM reports that reads VTBFHA directly and supports customer enhancements via:
- BAdI FTR_REPORTING
- Enhancement Spot ES_FTR_REPORTING
That’s why your fields appear there.
The other reports (TMR1, TX-3, S_ALR_87015205, TPM13) do not read VTBFHA directly.
They use logical databases, info structures, or valuation layers, which means:

Other Reports uses the logical database FTR.
To add custom fields:
Step 1 — Implement Enhancement
Use enhancement:
FTR_LDB_ADD_FIELDS (or customer include in structure FTR_S_POSITIONS)
Step 2 — Populate the fields
Use user exit:
Inside the exit, read VTBFHA and populate your custom fields.

entry.title: Re: Administration of Collar FX Option (Product Type 76A)
entry.content:
Dear Andersonm

Not in standard 76A functionality.
And the reason is structural:
SAP treats a Collar as one combined product with:
- A long Put
- A short Call
- A single net premium cash flow at inception
This is why SAP Help explicitly states:
“When you conclude a transaction, the cash flow consists only of the premium.”

SAP assumes the Collar is structured as a zero‑cost collar, or at least a single net premium, not two separate premium legs.
SAP’s 76A design:
- Generates one premium flow only
- Does not create two independent option legs
- Does not allow separate premium settlement dates for each leg
- Does not allow “premium on exercise” for one leg while the other is settled at trade date
This is a deliberate simplification: SAP models the Collar as a single instrument, not two linked options.

Banks typically settle:
- Put premium (paid)
- Call premium (received)
…on trade date, resulting in net zero.
This is a real‑world practice, but SAP’s 76A does not mirror this structure.

Model the Collar as two separate FX options:
- Product type 75A – FX Option (Put)
- Product type 75A – FX Option (Call)
This gives you:
- Two independent premiums
- Two independent cash flows
- Two independent exercise decisions
- Full control over settlement behavior
This is also the approach SAP recommends in consulting notes when banks require separate premium handling.


How to exercise one leg and close the other?
SAP provides three key functions for FX options:
1. Exercise (TPM20)
Use this for the option you want to exercise.
This will:
- Generate the FX settlement
- Post the exercise premium (if applicable)
- Close the exercised leg
2. Closeout / Early Termination (TPM18)
Use this for the option you do not want to exercise.
This will:
- Close the option at zero value (if it expires worthless)
- Post the final valuation adjustment
- Remove it from open positions
3. Automatic Expiry
If you do nothing, SAP will:
- Let the option expire worthless
- Post the final valuation at maturity
But for audit clarity, most treasury teams explicitly close the unexercised leg using TPM18.

Recommended operational process (best practice)
If you use 76A (standard Collar):
- You can exercise the Collar (TPM20)
- But you cannot selectively exercise only one leg
- You cannot post two premiums on trade date
- You cannot post premium on exercise
This does not match your bank’s process.
If you use two 75A options (recommended):
- Create two FX options (Put buy + Call sell)
- Post both premiums on trade date (net zero)
- On settlement date:
- Exercise the in‑the‑money option (TPM20)
- Close the out‑of‑the‑money option (TPM18)
This exactly matches your bank’s lifecycle.

Thanks

entry.title: Re: Financial Accounting 4 Advanced Execution Service Scenario in SAP S/4HANA
entry.content:

entry.title: Re: Step-By-Step Guide to Create SAP Integration Suite Trial Account and Assigning Required Roles
entry.content:
Yes, you can create and manage APIs in the SAP Integration Suite using an SAP BTP trial account.
Go to Security -> Select users -> Click Role Collection ->Click on 3dots ->Select below Roles and Assign Role Collection.

Required Roles:

  • APIManagement.SelfService.Administrator
  • AuthGroup.SelfService.Admin

For more details on other capability roles, please find SAP’s official guide on setting up user access in the Integration Suite. You can find the link below.

https://help.sap.com/docs/integration-suite/sap-integration-suite/configuring-user-access?locale=en…

And then Settings->Runtime->API Management(Activate).

entry.title: Re: SAP ECC vs S/4HANA Integration Capabilities: A Practical Guide for Integration Architects
entry.content:
Several statements in the post are not accurate and could mislead community members:

  1. OData Exclusivity to S/4HANA: The post claims OData is a "transformative" feature that "S/4HANA has that ECC doesn't", with tables marking it as unavailable in ECC without "workarounds". This is misleading. OData is supported in ECC through SAP NetWeaver Gateway, typically embedded in systems on NetWeaver 7.4 or later. It allows exposure of RFCs, BAPIs, and tables as RESTful services via transaction SEGW, enabling integrations like Fiori or Microsoft Power Platform connections. S/4HANA provides enhancements such as OData V4 and RAP, but Gateway is an official SAP component, not a workaround. This exaggeration creates an artificial gap, potentially discouraging valid ECC-based solutions.
  2. JSON Support as S/4HANA-Exclusive: The "What S/4HANA Adds Over ECC" table lists "No" for JSON in ECC. This is incorrect. ECC's Gateway supports JSON in OData V2 services via query parameters like $format=json, available since Gateway 2.0 (from 2011). JSON is inherent to OData, not an addition in S/4HANA.
  3. Event-Driven Integration Overstated as S/4HANA-Only: The table marks events as "Limited" in ECC and fully available in S/4HANA. ECC supports mechanisms like workflow events, change pointers, and output determination for near-real-time triggers, integrable with external brokers via PI/PO. S/4HANA standardizes business events, but Event Mesh is a BTP cloud service, not native to on-premises S/4HANA. This conflates on-prem and cloud, understating ECC's extensibility.
  4. SOAP Misrepresentation in ECC: Section 2.3 states ECC exposes SOAP services "using the Enterprise Services Repository (ESR)." ESR is part of PI/PO middleware, not ECC. Native SOAP exposure occurs via SOAMANAGER for ABAP services, without ESR for basic setups. 
  5. Protocol Matrix Inaccuracies: OData is marked "No" for ECC  and contradics the article's acknowledgment of Gateway. Events are similarly binary, and file interfaces are rated "Low" performance despite efficiency for batch use. 
  6. Cloud vs. On-Premises Inconsistency: The title focuses on "On-Premises systems," yet examples rely exclusively on cloud tools like CPI, BTP, and Event Mesh. On-premises alternatives (e.g., direct RFC/IDoc or PI/PO) are ignored, biasing toward SAP's cloud offerings.
  7. Additional Minor Issues:
    • BAPI characteristics note "Type-safe" parameters, but IDocs also feature typed segments.
    • IDoc table lists some types as "Outbound" only (e.g., INVOIC02), overlooking bidirectional support.
    • OData avoidance for bulk transfers overlooks batching capabilities.
    • API Business Hub is presented as an S/4HANA advantage, but it includes ECC APIs via Gateway.
    • Checklists downplay Gateway as a workaround while omitting its setup details.

Overall, the post is not very accurate and not a balanced guide. Architects should consult official SAP documentation for accurate information.

entry.title: A Wish for CLI-Based ABAP
entry.content:
A Wish for CLI-Based ABAP

Why modern SAP development needs to move closer to the terminal

Lately I’ve been thinking a lot about where SAP development is heading — and where it feels like it isn’t.

Outside the SAP ecosystem, development has moved decisively toward text-based, terminal-driven workflows. Code lives in Git, workflows start in the CLI, automation is the default, and AI tools increasingly operate directly on source files.

Inside the SAP world, especially around extensibility, we often see the opposite: GUI-driven tools, browser-based editors, and logic that gets generated somewhere behind the scenes.

After working hands-on with extensibility in S/4HANA recently, that contrast became impossible to ignore. It led to a simple but persistent thought:

What if ABAP fully embraced a CLI-based, developer-centric development model?

Modern development has moved to the terminal

For many developers today, the terminal isn’t a niche preference — it’s the center of gravity.

Modern development typically means:

  • source code as plain text

  • Git as the system of record

  • the terminal as the control plane

  • automation and pipelines by default

  • AI tools working directly on repositories

Tools like Claude Code make this very tangible. You can sit in a terminal, point the AI at a repository, ask it to explain a codebase, refactor a module, or generate a patch — all as diffs against real files. No wizards, no GUIs — just text in, text out.

Once you get used to working this way, it’s hard not to expect the same experience everywhere.

ABAP lives in a different world

ABAP, by contrast, still revolves around the SAP system itself.

  • Code primarily lives in the database

  • The system is the source of truth

  • Changes move via transports

  • Git integration is optional, secondary, and often awkward

  • Development assumes a running backend, not a repository

Even tools like abapGit, as valuable as they are, don’t change this fundamental model. They bridge worlds — they don’t redefine which world ABAP belongs to.

This means ABAP is not Git-centric. It’s not repository-centric. And as a result, it doesn’t naturally fit into modern CLI-based or AI-assisted workflows.

Low-code doesn’t fix this — it exposes it

SAP’s clean-core strategy has pushed heavily toward Key User Extensibility:

  • Custom Fields

  • Custom Logic

  • Adapt UI

  • GUI-driven configuration with generated artifacts

From a governance and upgrade perspective, this makes sense.

From a developer perspective, it often highlights the core problem.

Custom Logic is still ABAP — typed, structured, technical — but:

  • written in browser editors

  • without proper refactoring or navigation

  • without native Git ownership

  • without automation-friendly workflows

It ends up in an awkward middle ground:

  • too restrictive for developers

  • too complex for actual key users

Low-code doesn’t remove the need for strong developer workflows. It makes the absence of them more visible.

Clean core needs better developer ergonomics, not less code

Clean core is the right goal. There’s no debate there.

But clean core should not mean:

  • hiding code from developers

  • forcing logic into GUIs

  • discouraging automation

  • accepting weaker tooling

In practice, clean core works best with:

  • explicit, text-based code

  • strong testability

  • traceability through Git

  • automation and CI/CD

All of that aligns far better with CLI-friendly, developer-centric workflows than with click-driven configuration.

“CLI-based ABAP” is shorthand for a deeper change

When developers ask for CLI-based ABAP, they’re not chasing trends. And looking at how CAP is designed, SAP also knows this.

They’re really asking for:

  • ABAP source as first-class text

  • Git as a native concept, not a side channel

  • syntax checks, ATC, and tests callable from automation

  • workflows that don’t require a GUI or heavy IDE

  • AI tools that can reason about ABAP like any other language

This doesn’t mean pretending SAP systems aren’t special.
It means acknowledging that system-centric development no longer scales.

Why VS Code actually matters

This is why SAP’s move toward VS Code support for ABAP is so interesting.

VS Code isn’t just another editor. It sits at the center of:

  • Git-first workflows

  • terminals

  • automation

  • AI-assisted development

If ABAP can genuinely move closer to that ecosystem — even gradually — a lot suddenly becomes possible:

  • real CI/CD

  • better collaboration

  • meaningful automation

  • AI tools that work with ABAP, not around it

VS Code isn’t the goal.
It’s a signal.
